block.p: Introduced on Thursday: 2008 Subaru Impreza WRX

Is it real? It's the real thing -- the next WRX will come in four-door and five-door body styles. Subaru has officially shunned the word hatchback, as it is trying to move the WRX beyond the tuner world. Uh, good luck with that.
What's the point? Simple -- it's due for a change. Another factor: the next coming of the Mitsubishi Evolution is on the horizon.

What they said: "With this car, we have incorporated comfort and maximized room inside," said Akihide Takeuchi, program general manger of the Impreza WRX. "We have made it nice-looking and added fuel economy. So the car is more balanced."

What they didn't say: No matter how much Subaru wants to balance out the raw performance of the WRX with comfort, there's no getting around the fact that the WRX five-door will be the foundation of its next W.R.C. rally car, which means that performance always wins out.

What makes it tick? The good ol' 2.5-liter boxer engine has been tweaked with a new turbocharger and a new intercooler. It still puts out 224 horsepower, but the new combination should cure the WRX's notorious turbo lag. The WRX is built on a new platform with a wheelbase that's nearly four inches longer than the outgoing model.
How much, how soon? You can expect the prices to carry over when it goes on sale this summer: about $24,000 for the WRX (and $17,000 or so for the base Impreza).

How's it look? With this revamp, the WRX moves a bit more mainstream. The huge hood scoop is still there, but the lines are simpler. No funny bugeye lamps or cubic fender flares. Honestly, the four-door kind of looks like a Kia Rio while the five-door has a bit of a Daewoo Lanos in it. The interior redesign is a major improvement.
